mlDocs.author: Bhikkhu Sujato

sn46.52:3.2.pli: ‘etha tumhe, bhikkhave, pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe satta bojjhaṅge yathābhūtaṁ bhāvethā’ti.
sn46.52:3.2.en: ‘Mendicants, please give up the five hindrances—corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom—and truly develop the seven awakening factors.’

sn46.52:3.4.pli: ‘etha tumhe, āvuso, pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe satta bojjhaṅge yathābhūtaṁ bhāvethā’ti.
sn46.52:3.4.en: ‘Reverends, please give up the five hindrances—corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom—and truly develop the seven awakening factors.’

sn46.52:8.2.pli: ‘atthi panāvuso, pariyāyo, yaṁ pariyāyaṁ āgamma pañca nīvaraṇā dasa honti, satta bojjhaṅgā catuddasā’ti.
sn46.52:8.2.en: ‘But reverends, is there a way in which the five hindrances become ten and the seven awakening factors become fourteen?’

sn46.52:9.1.pli: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, pariyāyo, yaṁ pariyāyaṁ āgamma pañca nīvaraṇā dasa honti?
sn46.52:9.1.en: And what is the way in which the five hindrances become ten?

sn46.52:9.12.pli: Ayaṁ kho, bhikkhave, pariyāyo, yaṁ pariyāyaṁ āgamma pañca nīvaraṇā dasa honti.
sn46.52:9.12.en: This is the way in which the five hindrances become ten.

mlDocs.title:
Linked Discourses 46.52
6. Discussion
Is There a Way?

mlDocs.author: Bhikkhu Sujato

an10.61:2.4.pli: Pañcapāhaṁ, bhikkhave, nīvaraṇe sāhāre vadāmi, no anāhāre.
an10.61:2.4.en: I say that the five hindrances are fueled by something, they’re not unfueled.

an10.61:2.5.en: And what is the fuel for the five hindrances?

an10.61:3.1.pli: Iti kho, bhikkhave, asappurisasaṁsevo paripūro asaddhammassavanaṁ paripūreti, asaddhammassavanaṁ paripūraṁ assaddhiyaṁ paripūreti, assaddhiyaṁ paripūraṁ ayonisomanasikāraṁ paripūreti, ayonisomanasikāro paripūro asatāsampajaññaṁ paripūreti, asatāsampajaññaṁ paripūraṁ indriyaasaṁvaraṁ paripūreti, indriyaasaṁvaro paripūro tīṇi duccaritāni paripūreti, tīṇi duccaritāni paripūrāni pañca nīvaraṇe paripūrenti, pañca nīvaraṇā paripūrā avijjaṁ paripūrenti;
an10.61:3.1.en: In this way, when the factor of associating with untrue persons is fulfilled, it fulfills the factor of listening to an untrue teaching. When the factor of listening to an untrue teaching is fulfilled, it fulfills the factor of lack of faith … irrational application of mind … lack of mindfulness and situational awareness … lack of sense restraint …the three kinds of misconduct … the five hindrances. When the five hindrances are fulfilled, they fulfill ignorance.

an10.61:5.1.pli: Evamevaṁ kho, bhikkhave, asappurisasaṁsevo paripūro asaddhammassavanaṁ paripūreti, asaddhammassavanaṁ paripūraṁ assaddhiyaṁ paripūreti, assaddhiyaṁ paripūraṁ ayonisomanasikāraṁ paripūreti, ayonisomanasikāro paripūro asatāsampajaññaṁ paripūreti, asatāsampajaññaṁ paripūraṁ indriyaasaṁvaraṁ paripūreti, indriyaasaṁvaro paripūro tīṇi duccaritāni paripūreti, tīṇi duccaritāni paripūrāni pañca nīvaraṇe paripūrenti, pañca nīvaraṇā paripūrā avijjaṁ paripūrenti;
an10.61:5.1.en: In the same way, when the factor of associating with untrue persons is fulfilled, it fulfills the factor of listening to an untrue teaching. When the factor of listening to an untrue teaching is fulfilled, it fulfills the factor of lack of faith … irrational application of mind … lack of mindfulness and situational awareness … lack of sense restraint …the three kinds of misconduct … the five hindrances. When the five hindrances are fulfilled, they fulfill ignorance.

mlDocs.title:
Numbered Discourses 10.61
7. Pairs
Ignorance

mlDocs.author: Bhikkhu Sujato

an10.62:2.7.pli: Pañca nīvaraṇepāhaṁ, bhikkhave, sāhāre vadāmi, no anāhāre.
an10.62:2.7.en: I say that the five hindrances are fueled by something, they’re not unfueled.

an10.62:2.8.en: And what is the fuel for the five hindrances?

an10.62:3.1.pli: Iti kho, bhikkhave, asappurisasaṁsevo paripūro assaddhammassavanaṁ paripūreti, assaddhammassavanaṁ paripūraṁ assaddhiyaṁ paripūreti, assaddhiyaṁ paripūraṁ ayonisomanasikāraṁ paripūreti, ayonisomanasikāro paripūro asatāsampajaññaṁ paripūreti, asatāsampajaññaṁ paripūraṁ indriyaasaṁvaraṁ paripūreti, indriyaasaṁvaro paripūro tīṇi duccaritāni paripūreti, tīṇi duccaritāni paripūrāni pañca nīvaraṇe paripūrenti, pañca nīvaraṇā paripūrā avijjaṁ paripūrenti, avijjā paripūrā bhavataṇhaṁ paripūreti;
an10.62:3.1.en: In this way, when the factor of associating with untrue persons is fulfilled, it fulfills the factor of listening to an untrue teaching. When the factor of listening to an untrue teaching is fulfilled, it fulfills the factor of lack of faith … irrational application of mind … lack of mindfulness and situational awareness … lack of sense restraint …the three kinds of misconduct … the five hindrances … ignorance. When ignorance is fulfilled, it fulfills craving for continued existence.

an10.62:5.1.pli: Evamevaṁ kho, bhikkhave, asappurisasaṁsevo paripūro assaddhammassavanaṁ paripūreti, assaddhammassavanaṁ paripūraṁ assaddhiyaṁ paripūreti, assaddhiyaṁ paripūraṁ ayonisomanasikāraṁ paripūreti, ayonisomanasikāro paripūro asatāsampajaññaṁ paripūreti, asatāsampajaññaṁ paripūraṁ indriyaasaṁvaraṁ paripūreti, indriyaasaṁvaro paripūro tīṇi duccaritāni paripūreti, tīṇi duccaritāni paripūrāni pañca nīvaraṇe paripūrenti, pañca nīvaraṇā paripūrā avijjaṁ paripūrenti, avijjā paripūrā bhavataṇhaṁ paripūreti;
an10.62:5.1.en: In the same way, when the factor of associating with untrue persons is fulfilled, it fulfills the factor of listening to an untrue teaching. When the factor of listening to an untrue teaching is fulfilled, it fulfills the factor of lack of faith … irrational application of mind … lack of mindfulness and situational awareness … lack of sense restraint …the three kinds of misconduct … the five hindrances … ignorance. When ignorance is fulfilled, it fulfills craving for continued existence.

mlDocs.title:
Numbered Discourses 10.62
7. Pairs
Craving

mlDocs.author: Bhikkhu Sujato

an5.52:1.1.pli: “Akusalarāsīti, bhikkhave, vadamāno pañca nīvaraṇe sammā vadamāno vadeyya.
an5.52:1.1.en: “Mendicants, rightly speaking, you’d call the five hindrances a ‘heap of the unskillful’.

an5.52:1.2.pli: Kevalo hāyaṁ, bhikkhave, akusalarāsi yadidaṁ pañca nīvaraṇā.
an5.52:1.2.en: For these five hindrances are entirely a heap of the unskillful.

an5.52:1.5.pli: Akusalarāsīti, bhikkhave, vadamāno ime pañca nīvaraṇe sammā vadamāno vadeyya.
an5.52:1.5.en: Rightly speaking, you’d call these five hindrances a ‘heap of the unskillful’.

an5.52:1.6.pli: Kevalo hāyaṁ, bhikkhave, akusalarāsi yadidaṁ pañca nīvaraṇā”ti.
an5.52:1.6.en: For these five hindrances are entirely a heap of the unskillful.”

mlDocs.title:
Numbered Discourses 5.52
6. Hindrances
A Heap of the Unskillful

mlDocs.author: Bhikkhu Sujato

sn46.38:1.1.pli: Yasmiṁ, bhikkhave, samaye ariyasāvako aṭṭhiṁ katvā manasi katvā sabbaṁ cetaso samannāharitvā ohitasoto dhammaṁ suṇāti, imassa pañca nīvaraṇā tasmiṁ samaye na honti. Satta bojjhaṅgā tasmiṁ samaye bhāvanāpāripūriṁ gacchanti.
sn46.38:1.1.en: “Mendicants, sometimes a noble disciple pays attention, applies the mind, concentrates wholeheartedly, and actively listens to the teaching. At such a time the five hindrances are absent, and the seven awakening factors are fully developed.

sn46.38:2.1.pli: Katame pañca nīvaraṇā tasmiṁ samaye na honti?
sn46.38:2.1.en: What are the five hindrances that are absent?

sn46.38:2.3.pli: Imassa pañca nīvaraṇā tasmiṁ samaye na honti.
sn46.38:2.3.en: These are the five hindrances that are absent.

sn46.38:3.4.pli: Yasmiṁ, bhikkhave, samaye ariyasāvako aṭṭhiṁ katvā manasi katvā sabbaṁ cetaso samannāharitvā ohitasoto dhammaṁ suṇāti, imassa pañca nīvaraṇā tasmiṁ samaye na honti. Ime satta bojjhaṅgā tasmiṁ samaye bhāvanāpāripūriṁ gacchantī”ti.
sn46.38:3.4.en: Sometimes a noble disciple pays attention, applies the mind, concentrates wholeheartedly, and actively listens to the teaching. At such a time the five hindrances are absent, and the seven awakening factors are fully developed.”

mlDocs.title:
Linked Discourses 46.38
4. Hindrances
Without Obstacles

mlDocs.author: Bhikkhu Sujato

an9.64:2.1.pli: Imesaṁ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṁ nīvaraṇānaṁ pahānāya cattāro satipaṭṭhānā bhāvetabbā.
an9.64:2.1.en: To give up these five hindrances you should develop the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

an9.64:2.7.pli: Imesaṁ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṁ nīvaraṇānaṁ pahānāya ime cattāro satipaṭṭhānā bhāvetabbā”ti.
an9.64:2.7.en: To give up those five hindrances you should develop these four kinds of mindfulness meditation.”

mlDocs.title:
Numbered Discourses 9.64
7. Mindfulness Meditation
Hindrances

mlDocs.author: Bhikkhu Sujato

sn47.5:1.3.pli: “‘akusalarāsī’ti, bhikkhave, vadamāno pañca nīvaraṇe sammā vadamāno vadeyya.
sn47.5:1.3.en: “Rightly speaking, mendicants, you’d call these five hindrances a ‘heap of the unskillful’.

sn47.5:1.4.pli: Kevalo hāyaṁ, bhikkhave, akusalarāsi, yadidaṁ—pañca nīvaraṇā.
sn47.5:1.4.en: For these five hindrances are entirely a heap of the unskillful.

sn47.5:1.7.pli: ‘Akusalarāsī’ti, bhikkhave, vadamāno ime pañca nīvaraṇe sammā vadamāno vadeyya.
sn47.5:1.7.en: Rightly speaking, you’d call these five hindrances a ‘heap of the unskillful’.

sn47.5:1.8.pli: Kevalo hāyaṁ, bhikkhave, akusalarāsi, yadidaṁ—pañca nīvaraṇā.
sn47.5:1.8.en: For these five hindrances are entirely a heap of the unskillful.

mlDocs.title:
Linked Discourses 47.5
1. In Ambapālī’s Mango Grove
A Heap of the Unskillful

mlDocs.author: Bhikkhu Sujato

sn54.12:2.3.pli: Ye te, āvuso mahānāma, bhikkhū sekhā appattamānasā anuttaraṁ yogakkhemaṁ patthayamānā viharanti, te pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya viharanti.
sn54.12:2.3.en: Those mendicants who are trainees haven’t achieved their heart’s desire, but live aspiring for the supreme sanctuary from the yoke. They meditate after giving up the five hindrances.

sn54.12:3.1.pli: Yepi te, āvuso mahānāma, bhikkhū sekhā appattamānasā anuttaraṁ yogakkhemaṁ patthayamānā viharanti, te ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya viharanti.
sn54.12:3.1.en: Those who are trainee mendicants … meditate after giving up the five hindrances.

sn54.12:4.1.pli: Ye ca kho te, āvuso mahānāma, bhikkhū arahanto khīṇāsavā vusitavanto katakaraṇīyā ohitabhārā anuppattasadatthā parikkhīṇabhavasaṁyojanā sammadaññāvimuttā, tesaṁ pañca nīvaraṇā pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṁ anuppādadhammā.
sn54.12:4.1.en: Those mendicants who are perfected—who have ended the defilements, completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their own goal, utterly ended the fetter of continued existence, and are rightly freed through enlightenment—for them, the five hindrances are cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future.

sn54.12:5.1.pli: Ye te, āvuso mahānāma, bhikkhū arahanto khīṇāsavā vusitavanto katakaraṇīyā ohitabhārā anuppattasadatthā parikkhīṇabhavasaṁyojanā sammadaññāvimuttā, tesaṁ ime pañca nīvaraṇā pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṁ anuppādadhammā.
sn54.12:5.1.en: Those mendicants who are perfected—who have ended the defilements … for them, the five hindrances are cut off at the root … and unable to arise in the future.

mlDocs.title:
Linked Discourses 54.12
Chapter Two
In Doubt

mlDocs.author: Bhikkhu Sujato

sn45.177:1.5.pli: Imesaṁ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṁ nīvaraṇānaṁ abhiññāya pariññāya parikkhayāya pahānāya …pe… ayaṁ ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo bhāvetabbo”ti.
sn45.177:1.5.en: The noble eightfold path should be developed for the direct knowledge, complete understanding, finishing, and giving up of these five hindrances.”

mlDocs.title:
Linked Discourses 45.177
14. Floods
Hindrances

mlDocs.author: Bhikkhu Sujato

mn39:14.29.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu yathā iṇaṁ yathā rogaṁ yathā bandhanāgāraṁ yathā dāsabyaṁ yathā kantāraddhānamaggaṁ, ime pañca nīvaraṇe appahīne attani samanupassati.
mn39:14.29.en: In the same way, as long as these five hindrances are not given up inside themselves, a mendicant regards them as a debt, a disease, a prison, slavery, and a desert crossing.

mn39:14.30.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, āṇaṇyaṁ yathā ārogyaṁ yathā bandhanāmokkhaṁ yathā bhujissaṁ yathā khemantabhūmiṁ; evameva bhikkhu ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahīne attani samanupassati.
mn39:14.30.en: But when these five hindrances are given up inside themselves, a mendicant regards this as freedom from debt, good health, release from prison, emancipation, and a place of sanctuary at last.

mn39:15.1.pli: So ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe,
mn39:15.1.en: They give up these five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom.

mlDocs.title:
Middle Discourses 39
The Longer Discourse at Assapura

mlDocs.author: Bhikkhu Sujato

mn10:36.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati pañcasu nīvaraṇesu.
mn10:36.2.en: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of principles with respect to the five hindrances.

mn10:36.3.pli: Kathañca pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati pañcasu nīvaraṇesu?
mn10:36.3.en: And how does a mendicant meditate observing an aspect of principles with respect to the five hindrances?

mn10:37.4.pli: Evampi kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati pañcasu nīvaraṇesu.
mn10:37.4.en: That’s how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of principles with respect to the five hindrances.

mlDocs.title:
Middle Discourses 10
Mindfulness Meditation

mlDocs.author: Bhikkhu Sujato

dn13:30.1.pli: “Evameva kho, vāseṭṭha, pañcime nīvaraṇā ariyassa vinaye āvaraṇātipi vuccanti, nīvaraṇātipi vuccanti, onāhanātipi vuccanti, pariyonāhanātipi vuccanti.
dn13:30.1.en: “In the same way, the five hindrances are called ‘obstacles’ and ‘hindrances’ and ‘encasings’ and ‘shrouds’ in the training of the Noble One.

dn13:30.4.pli: Ime kho, vāseṭṭha, pañca nīvaraṇā ariyassa vinaye āvaraṇātipi vuccanti, nīvaraṇātipi vuccanti, onāhanātipi vuccanti, pariyonāhanātipi vuccanti.
dn13:30.4.en: These five hindrances are called ‘obstacles’ and ‘hindrances’ and ‘encasings’ and ‘shrouds’ in the training of the Noble One.

dn13:30.5.pli: Imehi kho, vāseṭṭha, pañcahi nīvaraṇehi tevijjā brāhmaṇā āvuṭā nivutā onaddhā pariyonaddhā.
dn13:30.5.en: The brahmins proficient in the three Vedas are obstructed, hindered, encased, and shrouded by these five hindrances.

mlDocs.title:
Long Discourses 13
Experts in the Three Vedas

mlDocs.author: Bhikkhu Sujato

mn99:15.5.pli: Imehi kho, māṇava, pañcahi nīvaraṇehi brāhmaṇo pokkharasāti opamañño subhagavaniko āvuto nivuto ophuṭo pariyonaddho.
mn99:15.5.en: Pokkharasāti is veiled, shrouded, covered, and engulfed by these five hindrances.

dn25:17.1.pli: So ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe
dn25:17.1.en: They give up these five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom.

dn22:13.2.en: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of principles with respect to the five hindrances.

dn22:13.3.pli: Kathañca pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati pañcasu nīvaraṇesu?
dn22:13.3.en: And how does a mendicant meditate observing an aspect of principles with respect to the five hindrances?

mlDocs.title:
Long Discourses 22
The Longer Discourse on Mindfulness Meditation

mlDocs.author: Bhikkhu Sujato

sn46.40:1.1.pli: “Pañcime, bhikkhave, nīvaraṇā andhakaraṇā acakkhukaraṇā aññāṇakaraṇā paññānirodhikā vighātapakkhiyā anibbānasaṁvattanikā.
sn46.40:1.1.en: “Mendicants, these five hindrances are destroyers of sight, vision, and knowledge. They block wisdom, they’re on the side of distress, and they don’t lead to extinguishment.

sn46.40:1.8.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca nīvaraṇā andhakaraṇā acakkhukaraṇā aññāṇakaraṇā paññānirodhikā vighātapakkhiyā anibbānasaṁvattanikā.
sn46.40:1.8.en: These five hindrances are destroyers of sight, vision, and knowledge. They block wisdom, they’re on the side of distress, and they don’t lead to extinguishment.

mlDocs.title:
Linked Discourses 46.40
4. Hindrances
Hindrances

mlDocs.author: Bhikkhu Sujato

sn46.2:1.3.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, pañca nīvaraṇā āhāraṭṭhitikā, āhāraṁ paṭicca tiṭṭhanti, anāhārā no tiṭṭhanti.
sn46.2:1.3.en: In the same way, the five hindrances are sustained by fuel. They depend on fuel to continue, and without fuel they don’t continue.

sn46.2:7.2.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, ime pañca nīvaraṇā āhāraṭṭhitikā, āhāraṁ paṭicca tiṭṭhanti, anāhārā no tiṭṭhanti.
sn46.2:7.2.en: In the same way, the five hindrances are sustained by fuel. They depend on fuel to continue, and without fuel they don’t continue.

mlDocs.title:
Linked Discourses 46.2
1. Mountains
The Body

mlDocs.author: Bhikkhu Sujato

an6.57:13.5.pli: So evaṁ pabbajito samāno pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe, catūsu satipaṭṭhānesu suppatiṭṭhitacitto, satta bojjhaṅge yathābhūtaṁ bhāvetvā akaṇhaṁ asukkaṁ nibbānaṁ abhijāyati.
an6.57:13.5.en: They give up the five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom. They firmly establish their mind in the four kinds of mindfulness meditation. They truly develop the seven awakening factors. And then they give rise to extinguishment, which is neither dark nor bright.

an6.57:16.5.pli: So evaṁ pabbajito samāno pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe, catūsu satipaṭṭhānesu suppatiṭṭhitacitto, satta bojjhaṅge yathābhūtaṁ bhāvetvā akaṇhaṁ asukkaṁ nibbānaṁ abhijāyati.
an6.57:16.5.en: They give up the five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom. They firmly establish their mind in the four kinds of mindfulness meditation. They truly develop the seven awakening factors. And then they give rise to extinguishment, which is neither dark nor bright.

mlDocs.title:
Numbered Discourses 6.57
6. The Great Chapter
The Six Classes of Rebirth

mlDocs.author: Bhikkhu Sujato

mn23:4.19.pli: ‘Caṅgavāran’ti kho, bhikkhu, pañcannetaṁ nīvaraṇānaṁ adhivacanaṁ, seyyathidaṁ—
mn23:4.19.en: ‘A filter of ash’ is a term for the five hindrances, that is:

mn23:4.21.en: ‘Throw out the filter of ash’ means ‘give up the five hindrances’ …

mlDocs.title:
Middle Discourses 23
The Termite Mound

mlDocs.author: Bhikkhu Sujato

dn10:2.12.1.pli: Evameva kho, māṇava, bhikkhu yathā iṇaṁ yathā rogaṁ yathā bandhanāgāraṁ yathā dāsabyaṁ yathā kantāraddhānamaggaṁ, evaṁ ime pañca nīvaraṇe appahīne attani samanupassati.
dn10:2.12.1.en: In the same way, as long as these five hindrances are not given up inside themselves, a mendicant regards them as a debt, a disease, a prison, slavery, and a desert crossing.

dn10:2.12.2.pli: Seyyathāpi, māṇava, yathā āṇaṇyaṁ yathā ārogyaṁ yathā bandhanāmokkhaṁ yathā bhujissaṁ yathā khemantabhūmiṁ.
dn10:2.12.2.en: But when these five hindrances are given up inside themselves, a mendicant regards this as freedom from debt, good health, release from prison, emancipation, and a place of sanctuary at last.

dn2:74.1.pli: Evameva kho, mahārāja, bhikkhu yathā iṇaṁ yathā rogaṁ yathā bandhanāgāraṁ yathā dāsabyaṁ yathā kantāraddhānamaggaṁ, evaṁ ime pañca nīvaraṇe appahīne attani samanupassati.
dn2:74.1.en: In the same way, as long as these five hindrances are not given up inside themselves, a mendicant regards them thus as a debt, a disease, a prison, slavery, and a desert crossing.

dn2:74.2.pli: Seyyathāpi, mahārāja, yathā āṇaṇyaṁ yathā ārogyaṁ yathā bandhanāmokkhaṁ yathā bhujissaṁ yathā khemantabhūmiṁ;
dn2:74.2.en: But when these five hindrances are given up inside themselves, a mendicant regards this as freedom from debt, good health, release from prison, emancipation, and a place of sanctuary at last.

sn47.12:6.9.pli: ‘yepi te, bhante, ahesuṁ atītamaddhānaṁ arahanto sammāsambuddhā, sabbe te bhagavanto pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya, cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe, catūsu satipaṭṭhānesu suppatiṭṭhitacittā, satta bojjhaṅge yathābhūtaṁ bhāvetvā, anuttaraṁ sammāsambodhiṁ abhisambujjhiṁsu.
sn47.12:6.9.en: ‘All the perfected ones, fully awakened Buddhas—whether past, future, or present—give up the five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom. Their mind is firmly established in the four kinds of mindfulness meditation. They correctly develop the seven awakening factors. And they wake up to the supreme perfect awakening.’”

mlDocs.author: Bhikkhu Sujato

an10.95:11.2.pli: Atha kho evamettha tathāgatassa hoti: ‘ye kho keci lokamhā nīyiṁsu vā nīyanti vā nīyissanti vā, sabbe te pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe, catūsu satipaṭṭhānesu suppatiṭṭhitacittā, satta bojjhaṅge yathābhūtaṁ bhāvetvā.
an10.95:11.2.en: But the Realized One knows that whoever is saved from the world—whether in the past, the future, or the present—all have given up the five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom. They have firmly established their mind in the four kinds of mindfulness meditation. And they have truly developed the seven awakening factors.

sn46.56:4.5.pli: Ekamekenapi kho, bhante, nīvaraṇena abhibhūto yathābhūtaṁ na jāneyya na passeyya, ko pana vādo pañcahi nīvaraṇehi?
sn46.56:4.5.en: Overcome by even a single hindrance you wouldn’t truly know or see, let alone all five hindrances.

mlDocs.title:
Anthology of Discourses 1.1
The Serpent

mlDocs.author: Bhikkhu Sujato

sn46.54:3.2.pli: ‘etha tumhe, bhikkhave, pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe mettāsahagatena cetasā ekaṁ disaṁ pharitvā viharatha, tathā dutiyaṁ, tathā tatiyaṁ, tathā catutthaṁ; iti uddhamadho tiriyaṁ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṁ lokaṁ mettāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyāpajjena pharitvā viharatha.
sn46.54:3.2.en: ‘Come, mendicants, give up these five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom, and meditate spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, spread a heart full of love to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
